The EAP is monitored and reviewed for suitability and effectiveness annually and updated as needed. The facility conducts an emergency exercise at least once a year on scenarios and/or elements of the Emergency Action Plan. During these exercises, Bakelite involves as many associates as possible within a single or multiple exercises and works to involve an outside emergency agency, if possible. Contractors, who periodically perform work in the plant, are prescreened prior to selection for work on-site. This prescreening review evaluates their safety programs and performance for any job that could impact process safety. Once selected, contractors are given safety orientations to brief them on plant hazards and safety practices. Incidents that cause, or could cause, a release are investigated with recommendations leading to improvements to help prevent recurrence. These recommendations include improvement of equipment, procedures, operating conditions, or training. Periodically, a safety professional from another Bakelite location conducts a comprehensive audit of the safety program. Addressing recommendations from this audit keeps the safety program effective.

4.	Five-year Accident History:

Bakelite has not had an off-site release of regulated substance during the five year period from October 12, 2017 to October 7, 2022. 

5.	Emergency Response Program:
The facility maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that discusses the steps to respond or evacuate in the event an accidental release occurs. The EAP contains several elements which include, but are not limited to, the following:
	A description of operations including a site plan, inventory of hazardous chemicals on-site, number of people likely on-site, and contact information.
	Description of the facility response preparedness including Incident Commander, emergency response equipment, emergency operations center, communication equipment, medical equipment, and rescue equipment.
	Incident command structure, response management descriptions, and plan for coordinating with local fire department responders and the Local Emergency Planning Committee.

Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) are conducted on an on-going basis to identify hazards and recommend safeguards to prevent an accidental release. Recommendations resulting from the PHAs are entered into an action item database to track the items to completion with multiple methods used to assure that changes to plant equipment, procedures, or processes do not cause accidents. All equipment and procedure changes initiates a safety review under the Management of Change (MOC) process. The MOC review process includes a PHA as needed for significant changes to the facility. Product formulations changes initiate a review by a chemist, process engineer, and the site leader. Training is provided to assure that those affected by the change understand its impact to the facility. Pre-Start-up Safety Reviews (PSSRs) are performed to assure that the plant can be started up safely after a significant change is made. A preventive maintenance program maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment using a computer database to manage the preventive maintenance schedule. Each month scheduled equipment inspections, tests, or equipment servicing is performed. The schedule is based on American Petroleum Institute (API) inspection frequency Standards 510 and 653, plant experience, and manufacturer recommendations to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release caused by equipment failure.

One critical aspect of the manual is the facility permitting process for the control of hazards during work activities. This safe work practice permitting process includes activities such as confined space entry, lockout tagout, and hot work. These safe work practices apply both to employees and contractors. 3.	Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

This facility has a Process Safety Management Program that is in compliance with the EPA Accidental Release Prevention rule, OSHA Process Safety Management rule, and all applicable state codes and regulations. A safety management system is in place to assure on-going compliance which includes the Safety Manual, a list of site safety responsibilities, a file system to maintain records of compliance, and a monthly safety committee meeting where a management control check sheet is used to verify tasks completed on schedule. Bakelites Site Leader has overall responsibility for this program and is responsible for keeping operating procedures up-to-date, training operators on these procedures, assuring that the plant is run safely on a daily basis, and when necessary, investigating incidents. All employees participate in the safety program through team-based activities to improve safety and plant operation. The Site Leader maintains an Operating Guide that includes process safety information, operating procedures, and a training certification program. 1.	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

As stated in our Environmental, Health, and Safety Policy, Bakelite Synthetics (Bakelite), is committed to safely manufacture and deliver our products by operating our sites in a responsible manner. This includes complying with applicable laws, responsibly managing risks, and working collaboratively with others to address health, safety, and environmental issues. In the Bakelite Safety Manual, it states that safety will not be compromised to achieve any operational or business objective. The Safety Manual defines requirements and guidelines developed to prevent injuries and accidental releases by appropriately managing the systems we have in place. Bakelites management and facility employees are committed to preventing any releases of ammonia (anhydrous and aqueous) and formaldehyde through the use of proper equipment, maintenance, routine inspections, and personnel training. In addition to the Safety Manual, Bakelites Emergency Response Policy reinforces safety being the top priority in all emergency response situations. The Emergency Action Plan contains specific procedures for handling releases of hazardous materials. In the event an accidental release does occur, the facility has coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee, local fire department, and regional Hazardous Materials Management (HAZMAT) response team to strategize for an appropriate response minimizing any impact of the release to people and the environment.

2.	Stationary source and regulated substances handled:

Bakelites Acme facility includes one formaldehyde manufacturing unit and one hexamethylenetetramine (hexamine) manufacturing unit. The formaldehyde unit converts methanol into formaldehyde through a catalytic oxidation process.
